**G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4**.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter under **G.L. c. 212, § 4** and **G.L. c. 223A, § 3**, because the tortious conduct occurred within the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.

**G.L. c. 223A, \u00a7 3**.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter under **G.L. c. 212, § 4** and **G.L. c. 223A, § 3**, because the tortious conduct occurred within the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.

**G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1**.proposition: Venue is proper in **Suffolk County Superior Court** pursuant to **G.L. c. 223, § 1** because the events giving rise to this action occurred in Suffolk County, and Defendant conducts substantial business therein.

**G.L. c. 85, \u00a7 11B**.proposition: Plaintiff was operating the bicycle lawfully, wearing a protective helmet, and exercising due care as required by **G.L. c. 85, § 11B**.

*Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc.*, 43.raw_text: *Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc.*, 438 Mass. 317 (2002)
*Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc.*, 43.proposition: At all relevant times, the driver acted as an employee, agent, servant, or ostensible agent of Defendant QuickRide Rideshare, LLC, which is vicariously liable under **respondeat superior** principles.
*Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc.*, 43.case_name: Dias v. Brigham Medical Associates, Inc.
*Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc.*, 43.support_reasoning: The case supports the general principle of respondeat superior—that an employer is vicariously liable for torts of its employee committed within the scope of employment—but it does not address rideshare drivers, ostensible agency, or facts analogous to a QuickRide driver. Dias involves an admitted, formal employee (a physician) of a medical practice group and discusses when an employer-employee relationship and scope of employment create vicarious liability. It therefore provides background authority on respondeat superior but does not specifically support the proposition that the driver here was an employee, agent, servant, or ostensible agent of QuickRide.
*Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc.*, 43.relevant_excerpt: “To prevail against BMA, the plaintiffs need only establish that (1) at the time of the alleged negligence Dr. Schlitzer was an employee of BMA, and (2) the alleged negligent treatment of the plaintiff occurred within the scope of Dr. Schlitzer’s employment by BMA. Once employment is established, the only remaining issue is whether he was working for BMA at the time of the alleged negligent treatment, i.e., whether his treatment of the plaintiff was within the scope of his employment by BMA.”

*Kelly v. Ryder Student Transp. Servs.,.raw_text: *Kelly v. Ryder Student Transp. Servs., Inc.*, 71 Mass. App. Ct. 759 (2008)
*Kelly v. Ryder Student Transp. Servs.,.proposition: At all relevant times, the driver acted as an employee, agent, servant, or ostensible agent of Defendant QuickRide Rideshare, LLC, which is vicariously liable under **respondeat superior** principles.
*Kelly v. Ryder Student Transp. Servs.,.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns criminal liability for receiving a stolen motor vehicle and the statutory definition of a ‘motor vehicle’ under Massachusetts law. It does not address employment relationships, agency, ostensible agency, or vicarious liability under respondeat superior, nor does it involve a corporate defendant like a rideshare company. Therefore, it provides no authority for the proposition that a driver was acting as an employee or agent of a rideshare company or that the company is vicariously liable.
*Kelly v. Ryder Student Transp. Servs.,.relevant_excerpt: The crime of possession of a stolen motor vehicle under G. L. c. 266, § 28(a), requires proof that (1) the motor vehicle is stolen; (2) the defendant possessed the motor vehicle; and (3) the defendant knew that the motor vehicle was stolen. Commonwealth v. Campbell, 60 Mass. App. Ct. 215, 217 (2003). As a threshold matter, however, the vehicle in question must be a motor vehicle.

*Mullins v. Pine Manor College*, 389 Mas.proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty of reasonable care to ensure that its drivers operated vehicles safely and in compliance with Massachusetts traffic and bicycle safety laws.
*Mullins v. Pine Manor College*, 389 Mas.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a college’s duty to protect a student from criminal assault (premises security and foreseeability), not any duty related to operation of vehicles or compliance with traffic or bicycle safety laws. Nothing in the excerpt, or in the Mullins case generally, addresses obligations of a defendant to ensure that its drivers operate vehicles safely or in accordance with Massachusetts traffic or bicycle statutes. Thus the case does not provide authority for the specific transportation-related duty described in the proposition.
*Mullins v. Pine Manor College*, 389 Mas.relevant_excerpt: The plaintiff had the burden of proving “that the defendant[s] took a risk with respect to the plaintiff’s safety that a person of ordinary prudence would not have taken, and that the plaintiff suffered a resulting injury that was within the foreseeable risk.” Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., 385 Mass. 323, 330 (1982). Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc., 355 Mass. 450, 454 (1969).

*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694 (2000.proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty of reasonable care to ensure that its drivers operated vehicles safely and in compliance with Massachusetts traffic and bicycle safety laws.
*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694 (2000.support_reasoning: The case concerns a premises owner/general contractor’s potential liability for injuries from a scaffolding collapse on his property, not any duty related to operation of vehicles or compliance with traffic or bicycle safety laws. The court expressly notes it need not decide whether the defendant owed a duty of care at all because plaintiffs failed to show causation. Nothing in the opinion addresses duties regarding drivers or vehicle operation, so it does not support the stated proposition.
*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694 (2000.relevant_excerpt: “The motion judge found that the plaintiffs had not shown the requisite control necessary to impose a duty on the defendant. Because the plaintiffs have failed to meet their burden on the issue of causation, we need not decide whether they presented sufficient evidence to show that the defendant owed a duty of care to them sufficient to survive the defendant’s motion for summary judgment. See St. Germaine v. Pendergast, 411 Mass. 615, 622-623 (1992) …”

**G.L. c. 90, \u00a7 14**.proposition: Under **G.L. c. 90, § 14**, no person shall open the door of a motor vehicle unless it is reasonably safe to do so and can be done without interfering with the movement of other traffic.

*Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, I.raw_text: *Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.*, 408 Mass. 355 (1990)
*Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, I.proposition: Defendant’s breach of this duty constitutes negligence per se.
*Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, I.case_name: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.
*Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, I.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly rejects the notion that violating the statute constitutes negligence per se. The court reiterates the Massachusetts rule that statutory violation is only some evidence of negligence and does not itself establish a breach of duty, directly contrary to the claimed proposition that breach of this duty is negligence per se.
*Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, I.relevant_excerpt: "It has long been the rule in this Commonwealth that violation of a statute does not by itself establish a breach of duty, for it does not constitute negligence per se. LaClair v. Silberline Mfg. Co., 379 Mass. 21, 28 (1979), and cases cited. Rather, violation of a statute such as § 69 is only 'some evidence' of the defendant's negligence as to all consequences the statute was intended to prevent."

*Ulwick v. DeChristopher*, 411 Mass. 401.proposition: Defendant’s breach of this duty constitutes negligence per se.
*Ulwick v. DeChristopher*, 411 Mass. 401.support_reasoning: The case expressly rejects the notion that violation of the cited alcohol-related statutes constitutes negligence per se in Massachusetts. The court reiterates the general rule that statutory violation “does not by itself establish a breach of duty” and holds that, absent an underlying common-law duty, these criminal statutes do not create civil liability. Thus, Ulwick is authority against, not for, the proposition that the defendant’s breach of such a statutory duty is negligence per se.
*Ulwick v. DeChristopher*, 411 Mass. 401.relevant_excerpt: "It has long been the rule in this Commonwealth that violation of a statute does not by itself establish a breach of duty, for it does not constitute negligence per se. LaClair v. Silberline Mfg. Co., 379 Mass. 21, 28 (1979), and cases cited."

*Cottam v. CVS Pharmacy*, 436 Mass. 316.proposition: Defendant further owed a duty to train and supervise its drivers to avoid foreseeable risks to bicyclists using the public roadways, as recognized under *Cottam v. CVS Pharmacy*, 436 Mass. 316 (2002) and *Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).
*Cottam v. CVS Pharmacy*, 436 Mass. 316.support_reasoning: The case concerns a pharmacy’s duty to warn customers about prescription drug side effects and the voluntary assumption of such a duty; it does not address duties relating to training or supervising drivers, roadway safety, or risks to bicyclists. While it discusses how common-law duties may be voluntarily assumed and defined, it provides no authority for a specific duty to train and supervise drivers to avoid foreseeable risks to bicyclists on public roadways. Therefore, citing Cottam for that transportation-related duty is inaccurate.
*Cottam v. CVS Pharmacy*, 436 Mass. 316.relevant_excerpt: “A pharmacy, like any other person or entity, may voluntarily assume a duty that would not otherwise be imposed on it, and thus may voluntarily assume a duty to provide information, advice or warnings to its customers. Massachusetts recognizes that ‘a duty voluntarily assumed must be performed with due care’… ‘If a person voluntarily assumes a duty or undertakes to render services to another that should have been seen as necessary for her protection, that person may be liable for harm caused because of the negligent performance of his undertaking.’”

*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).proposition: Defendant further owed a duty to train and supervise its drivers to avoid foreseeable risks to bicyclists using the public roadways, as recognized under *Cottam v. CVS Pharmacy*, 436 Mass. 316 (2002) and *Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).support_reasoning: Jupin concerns a homeowner’s duty to exercise reasonable care in the storage of firearms on her premises where a violent, mentally unstable person has unsupervised access. The court recognizes a duty regarding safe storage of dangerous instrumentalities, not any duty to train or supervise drivers, bicyclist safety, or roadway use. Thus Jupin does not support a proposition about a defendant’s duty to train and supervise drivers to avoid foreseeable risks to bicyclists on public roads.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “[W]e hold that a homeowner who permits a guest to keep guns permanently on her premises and allows a third person with a criminal history and mental difficulties unsupervised access to the property, has a duty to ensure that the firearms are properly and safely stored. We therefore reverse the grant of summary judgment on that claim and remand the case for further action.”

*Payton v. Abbott Labs.*, 386 Mass. 540.proposition: Defendant’s negligence was the direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s injuries, physical pain, emotional distress, and financial loss.
*Payton v. Abbott Labs.*, 386 Mass. 540.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly notes that negligence and causation are assumed only for purposes of answering certified questions and are not before the court for decision. The case focuses on whether Massachusetts recognizes certain causes of action (particularly negligent infliction of emotional distress without physical harm and prenatal injury claims), not on any finding that a defendant’s negligence was the direct and proximate cause of the plaintiffs’ specific injuries, pain, emotional distress, or financial loss. Thus it does not establish or affirm the causation proposition stated.
*Payton v. Abbott Labs.*, 386 Mass. 540.relevant_excerpt: "We note initially that neither the issue of negligence nor that of causation is before us. The certified question assumes both that the defendants were negligent, and that their negligence caused the plaintiffs' emotional distress." (386 Mass. at 545)

*Morgan v. Lalumiere*, 22 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Defendant’s negligence was the direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s injuries, physical pain, emotional distress, and financial loss.
*Morgan v. Lalumiere*, 22 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion accepts that the defendant (driver) was causally negligent and that his negligence contributed to the plaintiff’s injuries, but the jury specifically found both parties causally negligent and attributed a majority (52%) of fault to the plaintiff, which barred her recovery. The court’s role here is to uphold that comparative-fault allocation, not to hold that the defendant’s negligence was the direct and sole proximate cause of all of the plaintiff’s injuries, pain, emotional distress, and financial loss. Thus, the case does not support the broad proposition that defendant’s negligence was *the* direct and proximate cause of plaintiff’s injuries; it only supports that it was *a* proximate cause shared with plaintiff’s own negligence.
*Morgan v. Lalumiere*, 22 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “A review of the record convinces us that the jury’s finding that Lalumiere was causally negligent was amply supported, and no one argues to the contrary on appeal. … They found Morgan and Lalumiere both to have been causally negligent. They attributed fifty-two percent of the fault to Morgan and forty-eight percent to Lalumiere. Consequently, in the ensuing judgment, Morgan was not awarded any damages.”

**G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85**.proposition: Plaintiff’s comparative fault, if any, was less than 51% of the total fault, and Plaintiff is therefore entitled to recovery under **G.L. c. 231, § 85**.

*Shantigar Found. v. Bear Mountain Build.raw_text: *Shantigar Found. v. Bear Mountain Builders*, 441 Mass. 131 (2004)
*Shantigar Found. v. Bear Mountain Build.proposition: As a result of Defendant’s negligence, Plaintiff suffered and continues to suffer physical injuries, pain and suffering, lost wages, and expenses, and will continue to incur damages in the future.
*Shantigar Found. v. Bear Mountain Build.case_name: Shantigar Foundation v. Bear Mountain Builders
*Shantigar Found. v. Bear Mountain Build.support_reasoning: The case concerns allocation of comparative negligence and the treatment of settling tortfeasors under Massachusetts’ comparative negligence statute, along with admissibility of evidence about failure to install sprinklers. It involves only property damage to a barn and does not discuss personal physical injuries, pain and suffering, lost wages, medical expenses, or future damages to a plaintiff. Therefore it does not provide authority for the proposition that, as a result of a defendant’s negligence, a plaintiff suffered and continues to suffer those categories of personal injury damages.
*Shantigar Found. v. Bear Mountain Build.relevant_excerpt: On the evening of January 26, 2000, a fire destroyed a Nineteenth Century barn owned by the Shantigar Foundation in Rowe. ... The jury also found that Shantigar was negligent and that its negligence was a proximate cause of the fire. ... Bear Mountain asserts, and we agree, that the removal of absent tortfeasors from the jury’s consideration comports with the Legislature’s intent and is consistent with the Massachusetts statutory schemes of joint and several liability, and contribution.

*Hendrickson v. Sears*, 365 Mass. 83 (19.proposition: As a result of Defendant’s negligence, Plaintiff suffered and continues to suffer physical injuries, pain and suffering, lost wages, and expenses, and will continue to incur damages in the future.
*Hendrickson v. Sears*, 365 Mass. 83 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns when a legal malpractice claim for negligent certification of title accrues for statute of limitations purposes. It does not discuss the nature or extent of the plaintiffs’ damages such as physical injuries, pain and suffering, lost wages, or future damages. The case is purely about accrual and discovery of misrepresentation, so it does not support a proposition about personal injury damages resulting from negligence.
*Hendrickson v. Sears*, 365 Mass. 83 (19.relevant_excerpt: “According to the Court of Appeals, the complaint made the following allegations. … In June, 1970, the prospective purchasers refused to buy because of a recorded easement running through the premises, and the plaintiffs suffered a loss in effecting modification of the easement and in the ultimate sale of the property.”

**G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B**.proposition: e. Interest and costs as provided under **G.L. c. 231, § 6B**; and
